bcl:definition.bcl:text: board has the same meaning as in the Code;
Code means the Labour Relations Code;

collective agreement means a written agreement between an employer or an employers' organization authorized by the employer, and a trade union providing for minimum prices or prices of fish, share arrangements between vessel owners and crew members on fishing vessels, hours of work or other conditions of employment and includes any such agreement that was entered into before June 30, 1994 and that is still in force;
employee means a person engaged in commercial fishing and includes a person who agrees to accept as remuneration a share or portion of the proceeds of a fishing venture;
employer means a person who employs one or more employees and includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who purchases fish from a commercial fisher,
a person who provides as remuneration a share or portion of the proceeds of a fishing venture, and

bcl:definition.bcl:text: fish means any species of animal living in water, including its eggs or roe;

lockout means a lockout as defined in the Code and includes a refusal by an employer to accept or purchase fish, done to compel the employer's employees or to aid another employer in compelling that employer's employees to agree to conditions of employment;

strike means a strike as defined in the Code and includes a refusal to engage in fishing or to sell or deliver fish by employees in combination or in concert or in accordance with a common understanding.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Act applies to persons engaged in the catching or harvesting of fish and to persons purchasing fish.
The Code and the regulations under it apply in respect of the matters to which this Act applies, but if there is a conflict or inconsistency between this Act and the Code, this Act applies.
Nothing in this Act prohibits or terminates any voluntary recognition of trade unions by employers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An employer or a person acting on behalf of an employer must not refuse to purchase fish from a person because the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is or proposes to become or seeks to induce another person to become a member or officer of a trade union, or
participates in the promotion, formation or administration of a trade union.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), this Act must not be interpreted to limit or otherwise affect the right of an employer to make a change in the operation of the employer's business reasonably necessary for the proper conduct of that business.
Section 14 of the Code applies with respect to an act prohibited by this section.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 35 of the Code does not apply with respect to the sale of a fishing vessel.

Despite section 57 of the Code, a strike or lockout arising from collective bargaining in respect of a species of fish is not unlawful only because it occurs during the term of a collective agreement in respect of a different species of fish.
Section 84 (1) and (3) of the Code does not apply

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a collective agreement in respect of the price or minimum price of fish, or
to an employment relationship where the employer maintains no control over the discipline or dismissal of the employee.

bcl:section.bcl:text: When the board, under section 22.1 (a) of the Code, is determining whether a unit is appropriate for collective bargaining, it may consider, in addition to other matters it considers relevant, the manner in which negotiations in the fishing industry have taken place in the past, including such matters as whether negotiations have taken place based on fish species and gear type.

Section 55 of the Code does not apply to collective bargaining between a trade union and an employer if the trade union and the employer have negotiated one or more collective agreements with each other before June 30, 1994.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 32 (1) of the Code, an employer may alter the price or minimum price that it offers for fish while an application for certification is pending.
Despite section 45 (1) (b) of the Code, an employer may alter the price or minimum price that it offers for fish during the 4 month period following certification.
Despite section 45 (2) of the Code, an employer may alter the price or minimum price that it offers for fish if the term of a collective agreement that was in force between the parties has expired.
This section does not apply where the alteration is made in a manner inconsistent with section 5, 6, 9 or 11 of the Code or section 5 of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: It is not inconsistent with section 27 (1) (a) or section 48 of the Code for an employer to pay bonuses or make other payments to employees above the minimum price in a collective agreement.
This Act must not be construed to prohibit a refusal to purchase fish for a cause not constituting a lockout.
The board has exclusive jurisdiction to decide a question arising under this Act, including jurisdiction to decide

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that a person may be an employee for some purposes and an employer for other purposes, and
that the relationship between a person engaged in commercial fishing and a purchaser of fish constitutes an employment relationship.
